Fig 8 Theoretical insights on oxygen electrode reactions of YNxC4-x@Gra with hydroxylation effect Daomiao Wang Investigation Formal analysis Writing – original draft a Kang Wu Investigation Formal analysis a Tao Xu Methodology Conceptualization a Shaik Gouse Peera Resources Validation Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing b ⁎ Chao Liu Investigation Formal analysis Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ a School of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Materials Metallurgy and Chemistry, Jiangxi University of Science and Technology, Ganzhou 341000, People's Republic of China School of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Materials Metallurgy and Chemistry Jiangxi University of Science and Technology Ganzhou 341000 People's Republic of China aSchool of Materials Science and Engineering, Faculty of Materials Metallurgy and Chemistry, Jiangxi University of Science and Technology, Ganzhou 341000, People's Republic of China b Department of Environmental Science, Keimyung University, 1095, Dalseo-gu, Daegu 42601, Republic of Korea Department of Environmental Science Keimyung University 1095, Dalseo-gu Daegu 42601 Republic of Korea bDepartment of Environmental Science, Keimyung University, 1095, Dalseo-gu, Daegu 42601, Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding authors. The oxygen electrode reactions (ORR/OER) are the key to electrochemical storage and conversion technologies. In this study, the bifunctional electrocatalytic mechanisms of YNxC4-x@Gra with hydroxylation effect were discussed extensively. Firstly, the configurations with N coordination have good stability. Secondly, YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra with unstable coordination environment break the scale relationships between adsorption intermediates and exhibit outstanding OER performance with ηOER of 0.45 V and 0.46 V. Thirdly, YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1OH@Gra with stable coordination environment demonstrate excellent bifunctional activity with ηORR of 0.48 V, 0.54 V, and 0.53 V and ηOER of 0.71 V, 0.73 V, 0.63 V. Forth, for catalysts with stable coordination environments, there are scale relationships between the adsorption of intermediates, and thus volcanic curves were constructed. Finally, the d-electron number was introduced to predict catalytic performance, saving time and computative costs for screening potential catalyst configurations. All in all, YNxC4-x@Gra catalysts are potential oxygen electrode bifunctional electrocatalysts. Introduction The rapid fossil energy consumption has led to severe energy depletion and environmental damage [1]. It is urgent to explore clean and renewable energy. Electrochemical storage and conversion devices, such as metal-air cells and fuel cells, can convert clean energy into electric power, with high energy density, high energy conversion efficiency, low emissions and other characteristics [2,3]. Its popularity is expected to reduce dependence on fossil energy and improve the environment. However, the oxygen reduction reactions (ORR) [4,5] and oxygen evolution reactions (OER) [6,7] involved in the oxygen electrode have slow kinetics, which dramatically affects the charging and discharging efficiency of the battery, respectively. At present, platinum is commonly used for catalyzing ORR and oxides of iridium and ruthenium are widely used for catalyzing OER, which significantly improves the energy conversion efficiency of batteries. However, these precious metal catalysts suffer from the shortage of raw materials, high price, poor durability, low atomic utilization and single catalytic function, which greatly affect the further application and popularity of fuel cells and metal-air cells [8–13]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a catalyst with abundant raw materials, low cost, good durability, high utilization of active atoms and multi-functionality. Single-atom catalysts (SACs), in which the active component is anchored to the substrate vacancy in the form of a single atom, have high stability and 100% atomic utilization, which greatly reduces the amount of active component and lower production costs [14]. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have the advantages of low density, adjustable pore size, topological diversity, regular pore space, high porosity, sizeable specific surface area and tailorability. The synthesis of carbon-based catalysts by MOFs induction is the classical method for preparing SACs [15–17]. A large number of SACs for Fe, Co, et al. have been synthesized and applied in OER, ORR, etc. [18–21]. However, due to Fenton activity, the reaction selectivity is greatly affected [22–24]. Therefore, the catalytic potential of Fenton-inactive element is worth exploring [25]. As the first discovered rare earth element and one of the Fenton-inactive elements, the yttrium (Y) is widely used in rare earth functional materials such as rare earth aluminum alloys and so on [26,27]. Also, China has abundant concentrated yttrium and intermediate yttrium-concentrated europium deposits [28,29]. Recently, the ORR/OER catalytic activity of Y has begun to receive attention. Luo et al. studied the catalytic performance of Pt-Y2O3/C for ORR. The surface and mass specific activities at 0.9 V are 1.3- and 1.6-fold higher than that of Pt/C catalysts [30]. Ji and co-workers also found that YN4 exhibits excellent ORR activity after being activated by axial Cl radical [31]. Also, Kim et al. reported Y2Ru2O7−δ OER catalyst, the presence of Y enhances the stability of the catalyst [32]. Therefore, the bifunctional performance of Y SACs deserves further exploration. In the synthesis and DFT calculation of electrocatalysts, the N element is commonly used as the coordination atom for SACs [33,34]. The N atoms not only increase the stability for anchoring active metal; further, the appropriate number and the coordination structure of the N atoms can effectively modulate the electronic system of the active component to give it better catalytic activity [35,36]. In the experimental preparation, the N coordination number and coordination structure can be effectively regulated by adjusting the sintering temperature, which creates the conditions for the subsequent experimental verification of the theoretical research results [37]. Based on the DFT calculation, with graphene simulating a carbon substrate derived from MOF material, Y as the active atom, and N/C atoms regulating the electronic properties, Y-doped carbon-based catalysts (YNxC4-x@Gra) were designed for bifunctional electrocatalysts. The stability and electronic properties of each were first explored. Secondly, the bifunctional activity of the YNxC4-x@Gra bare catalysts were discussed. Thirdly, the effect of OH as the axial ligand on the catalytic activity was studied. Fourth, the scaling relationships between reaction intermediates were summarized, and volcanic curves were obtained. Finally, the outer d-electron number of the Y atom (εd) was introduced to describe the catalytic performance. Computational details Model construction and calculation methods Using a 5 × 5 graphene supercell to simulate the carbon substrate of the catalyst; and to avoid false interference between graphene layers, the vacuum layer was set to 30 Å. Dig out double vacancy in graphene supercell to simulate the defect of anchoring the Y single atom, and adjust the electronic structure of the active atom Y by changing the combination of the coordination atoms to stimulate the catalytic activity. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 1 , seven configurations were constructed, which may appear in the experimental synthesis. All DFT calculations were calculated by the DMOL3 program of Material Studio software [38]; and the solvation effect [39] of water and the van der Waals dispersion correction [40] were considered. The specific settings are provided in the supplementary information. Calculation formulas The formation energy (ΔEf) [41] and binding energy (ΔEb) [42] are calculated by: (1) Δ E f = E Y N x C 4 − x @ G r a + ( 2 + x ) E C − x E N − E Y − E G r a (2) Δ E b = E Y N x C 4 − x @ G r a − E Y − E N x C 4 − x @ G r a Here, E Y N x C 4 − x @ G r a , E C , E N , E Y , E G r a and E N x C 4 − x @ G r a are the energy of YNxC4-x@Gra, a C atom of defect-free graphene, 1/2 of an N2, Y atom, defect-free graphene and NxC4-x@Gra, respectively. x is the N atoms number. The formula of adsorption energy (ΔE*ads) [43] as follows: (3) Δ E * a d s = E * a d s − E a d s − E * Where E * a d s , E a d s and E * are the energy of intermediates, adsorbates and electrocatalysts, respectively. The adsorption free energy (ΔG*ads) [44] of intermediates is performed by: (4) Δ G * O O H = G * O O H − G * − ( 2 G H 2 O − 3 2 G H 2 ) (5) Δ G * O = G * O − G * − ( G H 2 O − G H 2 ) (6) Δ G * O H = G * O H − G * − ( G H 2 O − 1 2 G H 2 ) (7) Δ G * 2 O H = G * 2 O H − G * − ( 2 G H 2 O − G H 2 ) Where G * a d s and G * are the free energy of oxygen containing intermediates and catalysts. Fig. 2 shows the potential 4e− reaction mechanism in the alkaline environment. The clockwise direction is the ORR pathway, in which the pathways are * → *OOH → *O → *OH →* and * → *OOH → *2OH → *OH →*; and the opposite direction is the OER pathway. The reaction energy ΔGi of the elementary reaction step [45] is carried out by: (8) Δ G i = Δ E i + Δ Z P E i − T Δ S i − n e U + k B T l n 10 × p H Here, Δ E i is the reaction heat, Δ Z P E i and Δ S i are the change of zero-point energy and entropy. U and k B are the applied potential and Boltzmann. n is the number of electron transfers. T and p H are set to 298.15 K and 14. Usually, catalysts tend to favor energy-efficient pathways, so the overpotential η [46] is calculated by: (9) η O R R = { Δ G * → * O O H , [ ( Δ G * O O H → * O , Δ G * O → * O H ) m a x , ( Δ G * O O H → * 2 O H , Δ G * 2 O H → * O H ) m a x ] m i n , Δ G * O H → * } m a x / e + 0.402 (10) η O E R = { Δ G * → * O H , [ ( Δ G * O H → * O , Δ G * O → * O O H ) m a x , ( Δ G * O H → * 2 O H , Δ G * 2 O H → * O O H ) m a x ] m i n , Δ G * O O H → * } m a x / e − 0.402 The number of d electrons εd was counted by: (11) ε d = ∫ − ∞ ∞ E d ( ε ) d ε Where ε is the electron energy, E d ( ε ) is the d-orbital PDOS as a function of energy. Results and discussions Stability and electronic properties of YNxC4-x@Gra Whether it is the experimental synthesis or long-term work of catalysts, stability is an inevitable topic. Substances often evolve in a stable direction, and the stable catalyst configurations are more easily obtained in experimental synthesis. Furthermore, catalysts with stable configurations are less prone to corrosion in electrolyte environment and can maintain catalytic activity for a more extended period. Here, the synthesis stability of the catalyst was discussed through the formation energy ΔEf. The configuration with ΔEf < 0 eV indicates that the total synthesized energy is exothermic, which means it is more likely to be obtained in experimental synthesis. Fig. 3 (a) shows that the values of ΔEf gradually decrease with the increase of N atoms, indicating that the presence of N elements is beneficial for promoting the stability of the catalyst. At the same time, it can be seen that the ΔEf of three YN2C2@Gra configurations are similar, meaning that their generation possibilities in experimental synthesis are also comparable. Due to ΔEf > 0 eV, the probability of generating YC4@Gra is relatively low, so it is not discussed anymore. For the rest, the binding energy ΔEb between the Y atom and graphene vacancy is further calculated. Fig. 3(b) indicates that there is no apparent rule between ΔEb and N coordination number. Still, the ΔEb of all six configurations is smaller than the cohesive energy of hexagonal close-packed Y (hcp-Y) (-4.37 eV, [47]), which means that the Y atom can exist stably in these configurations without being prone to metal to metal polymerization, which also ensures the durability of the catalyst in long-term operation. In addition, Fig. S1 shows that after a period of molecular dynamics simulations, the Y atom remains firmly anchored in the graphene vacancy, further verifying their stability. The partial density of states (PDOS) and the Mulliken population of YNxC4-x were analyzed. As shown in Fig 4 , it can be seen that the up-spin and down-spin orbitals are completely symmetrical, indicating that YNxC4-x@Gra are anti-ferromagnetism; this means that the catalysts will not be affected by the magnetic field generated by electromagnetic induction, which is also beneficial for stability. The Y-N hybrid orbitals are lower than the Y-C hybrid orbitals, indicating that the Y-N bond is stronger and more conducive to the fixation of active atoms. But overall, all the orbitals of the six configurations are below the Fermi level, and chemical bonds are formed between the Y atom and the four coordination atoms. The Mulliken population analysis showed strong electron transfer between the central atom Y and the coordination atoms. At the same time, because the ability of the N atom to absorb electrons was stronger than that of the C atom, with the increase of the N atoms, the positive charge of the Y atom gradually increased, which would affect the catalytic performance. Further, the deformation electron density analysis was carried out. As shown in Fig. S2, compared with the isolated atoms, the blue and yellow areas indicate higher and lower electron density, respectively. (isovalue, ±0.07 e Å−3) The electron between the N/C atom and the Y atom is closer to the N/C atom, which means that the N/C atom has taken away some of the electrons belonging to Y. At the same time, compared with the C atom, the N atom has a stronger ability to attract electrons. All these are consistent with our judgment of electronegativity between Y, N and C [48]. The band structure analysis is shown in Fig. S3. The coordination configurations of 2 N atoms have good conductivity, while others exhibit semiconductor properties. Bifunctional mechanism of YNxC4-x@Gra electrocatalysts for ORR and OER In this section, the bifunctional mechanisms and performance of the YNxC4-x@Gra were discussed. Sabatier pointed out that high-performance catalysts not only need to have good adsorption of the reactant, but also should be able to desorb the product easily [49]. Therefore, the adsorption of potential reaction intermediates was first analyzed. The adsorption configurations and corresponding adsorption energy ΔE*ads are given in Table S1. For SACs, there are two main adsorption modes for oxygen: side-on and end-on. Due to the open space and strong adsorption, it can be seen that the vast majority of configurations only have side-on setup (Except for YN1C3@Gra). Compared to YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen@Gra with 2 N coordination, YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra have more powerful bonding ability for intermediates, especially for *O and *2OH configurations. This anomaly can be explained by the deformation electron density of YNxC4-xO@Gra in Fig. 5 . For YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra configurations, after the adsorption of the O specie, the electron density between the central atom Y and the two coordination atoms C almost disappears, indicating a weak interaction; This allows the Y atom to have more electronic orbitals to participate in the bonding with the O specie, thus showing abnormal adsorption. For YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra, after adsorbing the O, there is still a strong interaction between the Y atom and the four coordination atoms. The PDOS analysis in Fig. S4 also shows that after the adsorption of the O atom, the bonding between the central atom Y of YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra and the two coordinating C atoms weakens, while the central atom Y of YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra still maintains a strong interaction with the surrounding four coordinating atoms. Therefore, it can be concluded that the abnormal adsorption is caused by the unstable coordination environment. For YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra with a stable coordination environment, the adsorption of active center Y on intermediates increases with the increase of N atom number. This is because in the stable coordination environment, as the number of N atoms increases, the central atom Y gradually has a stronger positive charge, thus demonstrating an enhanced ability to capture intermediates. The adsorption free energy of oxygen containing intermediates and overpotential are listed in Table S2, and the reaction free energy diagrams are given in Fig. 6 (a-f). For ORR, the potential determination step (PDS) for all configurations is the desorption of the OH group, which have to overcome high energy, thus exhibiting poor ORR activity. For OER, YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra demonstrate excellent catalytic performance with ηOER of 0.45 V and 0.46 V, and the PDS is the elementary reaction step of *O to *OOH. This is because strong OH adsorption enables rapid activation of the reaction; then, compared to YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra, due to the exceptionally strong adsorption of O, the energy conversion from *OH to *O, and then to *OOH becomes smoother. Instead, YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra exhibit worse OER activity due to unsmooth energy conversion. The PDS of YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1@Gra is *OH to *O and that of YN4@Gra is *OOH to *. This means that the abnormal coordination environment will break the scale relationship of the catalyst's adsorption of intermediates, which may lead to higher catalytic activity under specific circumstances. Bifunctional mechanisms of YNxC4-xOH@Gra electrocatalysts for ORR and OER The hydroxylation of catalysts has received widespread attention in recent years [50-58]. In the experiment, Cao et al. observed OH vibrational peaks on Co1/PCN through FTIR, and XANES analysis ruled out water adsorption, proving the existence of OH species [56]. Further, Yang et.al investigated the effect of hydroxylation on FeN4 performance through the pH-dependent poisoning kinetics [58]. In theoretical calculations, the hydroxylation theory also provides a reasonable explanation for excellent catalytic activity [52]. In addition, a strong alkaline environment (pH=14) provides abundant raw materials and s stable environment for hydroxyl groups. Therefore, the effect of hydroxylation on catalytic activity was studied. Table S3 provides the configurations and corresponding adsorption energy of intermediates on YNxC4-xOH@Gra. For YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra, hydroxylation makes the adsorption of intermediates on the catalyst stronger or weaker, without obvious patterns, which is also caused by the unstable coordination environment. Especially, due to the formation of a bridge bond between Y-O-C, YN2C2hex@Gra exhibits abnormally strong adsorption of the O radical. For YN2C2oppo/N3C1/N4@Gra, after hydroxylation, the adsorption of the active atom Y on intermediates is weakened. As for YN2C2pen@Gra, hydroxylation also weakens the adsorption of most intermediates on the catalyst; but similar to YN2C2hex@Gra, it also exhibits exceptionally strong adsorption of the O radical due to the formation of bridge bond. Also, due to the spatial limitation caused by OH radical, all catalysts have an end-on mode for *O2. Of course, the side-on mode is still used here due to higher stability. Table S4 lists the adsorption free energy and corresponding overpotential, and Fig. 6(g-l) shows the reaction free energy diagrams of YNxC4-xOH@Gra. For YN1C3/N2C2hexOH@Gra, hydroxylation did not make the ORR reaction simpler, as the abnormal coordination effect made OH desorption more difficult; at the same time, hydroxylation also makes the electron step from *OH to *+O2 no longer smooth, resulting in poor OER performance. For YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4OH@Gra, hydroxylation increased the desorption efficiency of OH radical, and the ORR activity was significantly improved with ηORR of 0.48 V, 0.54 V, 0.53 V and 0.96 V, respectively; the PDS of YN2C2oppo/N3C1/N4OH@Gra is the *OH → *, and that of YN2C2penOH@Gra is * → *OOH. For OER, compared to corresponding bare catalysts, the PDS of YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4OH@Gra have been transferred to *2OH → *OOH with lower reaction energy, the OER performance has been explicitly improved with ηOER of 0.71 V, 0.73 V, 0.63 V and 0.88 V. Therefore, as shown in Fig. 7 , for the unstable coordination environment of YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra, hydroxylation did not result in higher catalytic activity; for YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra with stable coordination environment, hydroxylation effectively reduces the adsorption strength of the catalyst for intermediates, resulting in a significant increase in catalytic activity both for ORR and OER. The reaction always follows the optimal reaction path, so hydroxylation is also considered as one of the reaction paths to explore the optimal reaction path. Fig. S5-S7 show the reaction mechanism diagrams of the catalysts, the solid red line indicates the optimal reaction path. It can be clearly seen that YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra tend to react in the pathway without OH modified, while YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra are more inclined to react in the pathway with OH modified. Of course, the stability of hydroxylation will also affect the selection of reaction pathways. Accordingly, the Pourbaix diagram were created to discuss the stability of hydroxylation. As shown in Fig. S8, for YN1C3@Gra, the elementary reaction from *2OH to *OH is close to the reaction from *OH to *, which means that the reaction intermediate is easily converted from *2OH to *, indicating that OH modification cannot exist stably. For YN2C2hex@Gra, *2OH decomposes at a higher Uvs.SHE than *OH, meaning the instability of OH modified. As for YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra, the Uvs.SHE for desorption of OH ligand is lower than that of four elementary reactions, signifying that OH ligand will not undergo desorption during the reaction process, implying the stability of hydroxylation. In summary, both the reaction mechanisms and the stability analysis of hydroxylation indicate that YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra tend to react on the site without OH modification, while YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1/N4@Gra tends to react on the site with hydroxylation. The scale relationship between intermediates and the volcanic curve The adsorption of intermediates by YNxC4-x@Gra and YNxC4-xOH@Gra was analyzed in this section. To avoid interference from the unstable coordination environment, YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra and corresponding hydroxylation adsorption configurations were ruled out, and the abnormal *O configuration of YN2C2penOH@Gra was also excluded. Firstly, the scale relationship between various adsorption intermediates was explored, as shown in Fig. 8 (a). Taking the adsorption free energy of hydroxyl group ΔG*OH as the horizontal axis and that of other intermediates ΔG*ads as the vertical axis, robust scale relationship can be obtained. As ΔG*OH increases, ΔG*ads also gradually increase. Among them, ΔG*OOH can be described by ΔG*OH as a function of Δ G * O O H = 0.98 Δ G * O H + 3.31 with the coefficient of determination (R2) of 0.98; ΔG*O could be defined as 1.58 Δ G * O H + 2.26 with R2 of 0.98; and Δ G * 2 O H = 1.74 Δ G * O H + 0.80 with R2 of 0.97. The adsorption of intermediates in YNxC4-xOH@Gra is on the same straight line as that in YNxC4-xOH@Gra, which means that in a stable coordination environment, hydroxylation does not change the scale relationship between adsorbed intermediates. Based on the scale relationship and overpotential formulas, the volcanic curve diagrams for ORR and OER were constructed as shown in Fig. 8(b-c). With the increase of ΔG*OH, the ORR PDS changes from the step of *OH →* to the step of * →*OOH, showing a single volcanic curve relationship; while the OER PDS changes from the step of *OOH →* to the step of *OH →*O, then to the step of *2OH →*OOH, and finally to the step of *OH →*2OH, showing a dual volcanic curve relationship. It can be seen that hydroxylation enhances catalytic activity by weakening adsorption. However, when crossing the peak of the volcano, further weakening of adsorption increases the overpotential. The primary function of hydroxylation is to neutralize the excessive adsorption of intermediates by the catalyst, which also indicates that the improvement of catalytic activity by hydroxylation is limited. Due to the enormous time and computational cost of obtaining reaction free energy, finding an easily accessible descriptor to quickly predict catalytic performance will significantly improve the screening efficiency for potential catalysts. For this study, adjusting the coordination environment and hydroxylation are essentially adjustments to the electronic properties of the active Y atom, which will react on the number of electrons in the outer orbital. Therefore, the outer d-electron number of the Y atom (εd) was introduced to describe the catalytic performance. Similarly, it is also to construct the scale relationship between εd and ΔG*ads. Fig. 8(d) indicates a strong linear relationship between εd and ΔG*ads, where Δ G * O O H = − 0.59 ε d + 5.34 with R2 of 0.96, Δ G * O = − 0.89 ε d + 5.32 with R2 of 0.94, Δ G * 2 O H = − 1.04 ε d + 4.40 with R2 of 0.95 and Δ G * O H = − 0.60 ε d + 2.07 with R2 of 0.97. The volcanic curve shapes of ORR and OER in Fig. 8(e-f) are similar to those in Fig. 8(b-c), with the same height of the volcano and the basically consistent distribution of catalyst configurations. All of this indicates that εd can effectively describe the performance and will provide convenience for catalyst screening. Conclusions In summary, the bifunctional mechanisms of YNxC4-x@Gra were studied by DFT calculations in this study. Firstly, the N atom can effectively anchor the active atom Y, and the configurations with N coordination have good stability. Secondly, YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra with unstable coordination environment break the scale relationships between adsorption intermediates and exhibit outstanding OER activity with ηOER of 0.45 V and 0.46 V. Thirdly, for YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1@Gra with stable coordination environment configuration, hydroxylation effectively reduces the adsorption strength of the catalyst for intermediates, YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1OH@Gra exhibit excellent bifunctional performance with ηORR of 0.48 V, 0.54 V, and 0.53 V and ηOER of 0.71 V, 0.73 V, 0.63 V. Forth, for catalysts with stable coordination environment, there are scale relationships between the adsorption of intermediates, which will not be broken by hydroxylation, and thus volcanic curves were constructed. Finally, the d-electron number was introduced to predict catalytic activity, saving time and computational costs for screening potential catalyst configurations. All in all, YNxC4-x@Gra catalysts are potential oxygen electrode bifunctional electrocatalysts. coredata.dc:description: The oxygen electrode reactions (ORR/OER) are the key to electrochemical storage and conversion technologies. In this study, the bifunctional electrocatalytic mechanisms of YNxC4-x@Gra with hydroxylation effect were discussed extensively. Firstly, the configurations with N coordination have good stability. Secondly, YN1C3/N2C2hex@Gra with unstable coordination environment break the scale relationships between adsorption intermediates and exhibit outstanding OER performance with ηOER of 0.45 V and 0.46 V. Thirdly, YN2C2oppo/N2C2pen/N3C1OH@Gra with stable coordination environment demonstrate excellent bifunctional activity with ηORR of 0.48 V, 0.54 V, and 0.53 V and ηOER of 0.71 V, 0.73 V, 0.63 V. Forth, for catalysts with stable coordination environments, there are scale relationships between the adsorption of intermediates, and thus volcanic curves were constructed. Finally, the d-electron number was introduced to predict catalytic performance, saving time and computative costs for screening potential catalyst configurations. All in all, YNxC4-x@Gra catalysts are potential oxygen electrode bifunctional electrocatalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Theoretical insights on oxygen electrode reactions of YNxC4-x@Gra with hydroxylation effect
